Award.AwardTitle: LTREB RENEWAL: Collaborative Research: Population- and community-level mechanisms of range limitation in a variable and changing environment
Award.AbstractNarration:
Anticipating the effects of global climate change requires an understanding of how the abundances and geographic distributions of plants and animals will respond to altered weather patterns. This project continues a long-term study of two alpine plants from northern Alaska to the high alpine of New Mexico. Data collected to date show that near their southern limits, both species show declining survival but higher growth. These compensatory responses mitigate climate effects in most years, but break down in the warmest years. Over the next five years, the project will gather more detailed data to tie these ecological responses to local and regional climate and use climate change predictions to project the future range limits of the species.

Understanding how climate, and climate change, determine ecological dynamics is a central requirement for understanding when, where, and why climate change will or will not have serious consequences. This research will build capacity to anticipate climate change impacts, including the development of field and population modeling methods that can be extended to other species and ecosystems. Beyond the applied benefits of this understanding, the work will contribute to long-standing questions about the forces that naturally set range limits and determine patterns of biological diversity. The research incorporates both formal training in field and modeling methods to graduate and undergraduate students and informal education to the general public. The latter includes active involvement in non-profit education centers, public lectures through the National Park Service, and a series of articles written for the popular media.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Anticipating how the geographical ranges of species will shift is a major challenge in projecting the ecological effects of global climate change, as these shifts synthesize many of the most dramatic impacts likely to result from climate change. Predicting range shifts accurately will require an understanding of why species do not occur beyond their range limits. While this may seem easy to understand, two major complications make it a challenge. First, rare years may be disproportionately important in limiting where a species can exist. Second, different aspects of performance may react in different ways to climate. For example, warmer temperatures may increase growth rates, but also reduce survival. It is also important to understand individual differences in climate responses to predict how entire populations will be effected by climate changes.

Because of these difficulties, we have few data sets that allow testing of the different ways that climate change will exert its ecological effects. This study continued a long-term, large scale  effort to provide this information for two widely dispersed species, both tundra plants that live in both arctic and alpine habitats. We monitored over 20,000 individual plants over the six years of the study, at sites ranging from arctic Alaska to high elevation alpine areas in New Mexico. For each site and plant, we measured growth, survival and reproduction in each year of the study, and we measured aspects of climate that likely influence plant performance.

Our work shows both how resilient species can be to climate variation, and also what can limit this resilience. As suggested above, our work provides strong evidence that different aspects of performance react differently to climate. Survival and establishment of young plants is typically reduced under warmer conditions, while growth rate is increased. These opposing effects means that populations can remain stable over a fairly wide range of climate conditions, explaining how wide-spread species are able to persist across broad areas with a range of climates.

However, an equally important finding of our work documents two limitations in this resistance to climate variation. First, we find that the opposing effects of warming on different aspects of performance break down under the warmest conditions encountered during our study, when all aspects of plant performance suffered. This finding is important, as it explains why we may see very little effect of climate change up to a ?tipping point? and then extremely dramatic effects. Second, we have explored the extent to which plants in different regions have adapted to their historic climates and thus have different thresholds for tolerable warming. We find that there is considerable variation in the optimal or tolerable conditions, showing that individuals are adapted to the local conditions that have historically characterized their home sites. This is a particularly important finding, as it shows that estimates of a species? climatic tolerances based upon its entire geographic range may dramatically overestimate the ability of any one population to persist in the face of climate change. Since the majority of efforts to predict range shifts with climate change ignore local adaptation, this finding suggests that our predictions of the effects on climate change are generally too optimistic, and that much greater impacts on species ranges are likely than have commonly been suggested.

In addition to adding knowledge about climate change impacts, our study has also had other benefits for society. We have provided scientific and professional training to multiple students, including experiences collected, analyzing and interpreting scientific data. We have supported and given professional development opportunities to one postdoctoral researcher. We have also used the knowledge and experienced gained in this project to address multiple other ecological issues, and in particular have contributed to analyses that seek to improve the management of a diversity of endangered or threatened plant and animal species.
